Knowledge Base - Demonstrated competence in university level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the program.
Problem Analysis - An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

Investigation - An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.

Design - An ability to design solutions for complex, open-ended engineering problems and to design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate attention to health and safety risks, applicable standards, and economic, environmental, cultural and societal considerations.
Communication Skills - An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.

Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking and listening, and the ability to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.
Professionalism - An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.
Impact of Engineering - An ability to analyze social and environmental aspects of engineering activities.

Such ability includes an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society, the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.

Lifelong Learning - An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world in ways sufficient to maintain their competence and to allow them to contribute to the advancement of knowledge.

topics: Probability and Statistics Fall 2024
Mengqi Xu
Analysis of experimental measurements.

"This course deals with the understanding and application of probability and statistical principles so that we may further our knowledge of any given area of interest through the appropriate collection and analysis of data in the presence of uncertainty and random variation.

Focus will be more on the concepts and logic of statistics and the statistical method than on rote application of learned algorithms and ‘formulas’ (e.g. more on the ‘what’ and ‘why’ than on the ‘how’ of our calculations).
(a) summarize and identify important characteristics of a dataset using graphical and numerical methods (1)
(c) explain the concept and logic of statistical inference in terms of a parameter, a statistic, a population, a sample, and a probability distribution of a random variable (1)
(d) explain the concept of and conduct/create a hypothesis test and confidence interval for a parameter of interest, and interpret the results in the context of the study (1, 2)
(f) devise and implement a statistical study to answer questions about a population of interest (2, 3)

Inner product spaces and orthogonality.
Interpolation and curve-fitting.
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization, singular value decomposition.

Linear algebra, in a nutshell, is the study of linear transformations in a ﬁnite‐dimensional ﬁeld.

The foundations of human progress is built atop the concepts of LA – from the elements of Newtonian classical mechanics (force, gravity, momentum) to the ‘AI revolution’ today, everything is enwrapped by the beauty of vectors, ﬁnite‐dimensional spaces, and linear transformations.

In Systems Design Engineering, it is applicable in modelling and simulation, mechatronics, intelligent systems, signal analysis, machine learning, image processing and computer graphics, human factors, ﬁnancial and economic modelling, optimization, software engineering, and so on.

In this course, you will learn about diﬀerent mathematical concepts such as vector spaces, basis, span, independence, eigen values and vectors, and certain useful techniques like Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) and the Gramm‐Schmidt algorithm.
The core focus of this course is on applying what you learn – we will pursue both theoretical proofs and learn to practically apply the concepts via Python (our preferred programming language).
Appreciate the generality of linear algebra concepts by formulating and solving engineering problems in a vector space context.
Formulate and solve mathematical problems using appropriate linear algebra concepts and techniques.

Fundamental concepts in systems involving fluid flow.
Basic treatment of statics, kinematics and dynamics of fluids.

major_name: Systems Design Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Introduction to Control Systems Winter 2025
Kimia Dinashi                 Email: kdinashi@uwaterloo.ca
Classical and state space representations of control systems.
Routh-Hurwitz and root-locus methods.
Pole placement, PID, phase-lead and phase-lag controllers.
Introduction to Control Systems introduces the Systems Design Engineering student to the design and analysis of linear control systems.

The course covers the essential ideas of feedback, a review of Laplace transforms, transfer functions, block diagrams, time-domain performance specifications, the effects of pole-zero locations, stability of LTI systems, Routh-Hurwitz criterion, PID feedback control, Root-Locus design method, single-input single-output systems analysis and control methods in the frequency domain (Bode and Nyquist), phase lead & phase lag controllers, system description in state-space and state-variable feedback control design techniques.
Explain Laplace transforms, key components of feedback control systems, transfer functions, PID controllers, and main response characteristics of control systems (GAs: 1a, 1d).
Formulate, model, and solve properly control systems design and analysis problems (GA: 2a, 2b, 2c).
Apply block diagram reduction methods to find the overall transfer function of a given feedback control system (GA: 1d).
Apply the Routh-Hurwitz criterion to investigate the stability of an LTI system for different values of the control system parameters (GA: 1d).
Apply the Root-Locus method to tune the gains of PI, PD, or PID controllers for a given set of time-domain response characteristics (GA: 4b).
Construct and interpret the Bode diagram (magnitude and phase) for a given LTI control system (GA: 1d).
Apply the Nyquist criterion to investigate the stability of a given LTI control system for different values of the control system parameters (GA: 1d).
Employ computer programs and engineering tools properly for control systems design and analysis (GA: 5c).
Work effectively in a teamwork environment as a member and leader for solving control systems design and analysis (GA: 6a, 6b).
An introduction to Control Systems, Open-Loop, Feedback Control & Mathematical Models, Solving ODEs by Laplace Transforms.
Transfer Function, Poles, Zeros, Block Diagrams, Block Diagram Reduction & Pole Location, First-order Systems Response Characteristics.
Second Order Systems Response Characteristics & Response of Higher Order Systems.
Characteristic Equation, Stability Analysis & Routh-Hurwitz Criterion, Examples.
Feedback Control System Characteristics, Sensitivity, Disturbance Rejection & Steady-State Error, System Type.
Design and Analysis by Root Locus Method, Construction Rules & Examples.
Root-Locus Controller Design & Frequency Response Analysis and Design Method.
Mar. 17-
Resonant Frequency & Peak Value, Polar Plots, Nyquist Stability Criterion.
Nyquist Criterion Examples & Relative Stability Analysis.
Phase-lead & Phase-lag Controllers & Group Project Presentations.

topics: Optimization and Numerical Methods Fall 2024
- Abbas Seifi, Professor   Email: aseifi@uwaterloo.ca
Advanced methods for systems of linear equations.
Linear programming, simplex and interior-point methods.
Local and global optimization methods.
This course introduces the applications of optimization modeling and numerical methods to various engineering optimization problems.
It provides an overview of the formulation and classification of optimization problems arising in engineering and types of suitable optimization methods.

Graphical solution methods for two-variable problems and optimization techniques for single-variable problems like region elimination approaches, interpolation algorithms, and direct root-finding methods are discussed.
Linear Programming problem formulations and simplex and interior-point methods for solving such problems are discussed.
Learn about different types of optimization problems in engineering design (GA: 1,4)

2. Study types of optimizations methods and where they are applied, convexity, optimality criteria for unconstrained multivariable problems, and optimality conditions for constrained multivariable problems and proper software tools (GA: 1,2,5)

Apply graphical solution method to solve two-variable optimization problems, and region elimination methods, interpolation methods, and direct root-finding methods to solve single-variable problems (GA: 1,2,5)
Apply simplex and interior-point methods for solving Linear Programming problems (GA: 1,2,5)
7. Apply constrained multivariable methods as well as multi-objective techniques to solve design optimization problems using Pareto optimality concept(GA: 3,4,5)

major_name: Systems Design Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Biomechanics of Human Movement Fall 2024
This course introduces students to the biomechanics of the musculoskeletal system, including motor control and rehabilitation engineering.
Motor control will be included, as well as the identification of body segment parameters and the dynamics of muscles.
Biomechanics applies techniques of engineering mechanics to the study of biological organisms.
This course is specifically concerned with “musculoskeletal biomechanics”, the application of engineering mechanics to the study of the human musculoskeletal system.
We will further limit our interest to the use of kinematics and rigid-body dynamics to model the human body and its movement.

During this process, you will become well versed in the patterns of human motion, inverse and forward dynamic analyses of human motion, robotics, model development and validation, and interpretation of model predictions.
Assumed knowledge: The course assumes knowledge of basic concepts in statics, linear algebra, differential equations, and elementary dynamics.

topics: Transit Planning and Operations Winter 2025
The historical evolution of transit in cities; the technological innovations which made transit possible; and transit mode definitions.
System operational characteristics are defined and quantitative measures of effectiveness are introduced.
Methods for selecting appropriate transit modes are covered.
The focus of this course is on the use of quantitative techniques to analyse and solve problems arising in the planning, design, operation and management of urban public transportation systems.

Topics include an introduction to public transportation modes, transit performance analysis, fleet sizing and route design; control of transit operations, and paratransit planning, scheduling and dispatching.

The course also covers various transit modelling issues arising in the Advanced Public Transportation Systems that aim at maximising transit system efficiency and reliability using emerging technologies such as global positioning systems (GPS), electronic fare payment, and automatic passenger counters and pre-trip/en-route passenger information systems.

Profiling computer systems; bottlenecks, Amdahl's law.
View requirements for ECE 459
Many modern software systems must process large amounts of data, either in the form of huge data sets or vast numbers of (concurrent) transactions.
This course introduces students to techniques for profiling, rearchitecting, and implementing software systems that can handle industrial-sized inputs.
These techniques will enable you to design and build critical software infrastructure, especially in an age of Big Data.
While you may have seen some of these ideas in the context of operating systems (ECE350/SE350/CS350/MTE241) and concurrency (ECE252/CS343), this course gives you tools to make code run faster.

I highly encourage the students to meet with Farid first for their questions.
Principles of the geometry of motion, uniform and non-uniform motion, linkage, and analysis of mechanisms.
Consideration of the static and dynamic forces in machines.
We will study single-degree-of-freedom systems, multiple-degree-of-freedom (lumped mass) systems, and modal analysis for vibration problems in the first part of the course.
The first part of the course heavily depends on your previous courses in Dynamics, Differential Equations and Linear Algebra.
You are expected to know/learn MATLAB and Linear Algebra very well.
This course is very mathematical, but we also discuss some real-life examples of dynamic systems.
Concepts of degrees of freedom and inversion mechanisms will be discussed.
Finally, different kinds of gears and the fundamental law of toothed gearing will be discussed.

Fundamentals of autonomous mobile robotics, including both perception and planning for autonomous operation, sensor modelling, vehicle state estimation using Bayes Filters, Kalman Filters, and Particle Filters as well as onboard localization and mapping.
Topics in planning include vehicle motion modelling and control, as well as graph based and probabilistic motion planning of (Micro Electro Mechanical Systems) MEMS devices.
This course covers four fundamental topics of Autonomous Mobile Robotics; 1) modeling, 2) sensors and perception, 3) estimation (localization and mapping), 4) planning and navigation.
Modeling covers kinematic models of various types of wheeled mobile robots.
Sensors include various types and algorithms (for vision and range sensors).
Estimation includes Bayesian estimation theory and its application to localization (and/or mapping).
Topics in Planning include odometry motion models and graph-based and probabilistic motion planning as well as obstacle avoidance (reaction-based) methods.

topics: Notice of Recording
Introduction to Complex Systems Winter 2025
Professor Paul Fieguth pfieguth@uwaterloo.ca Office Hours: Mondays 4-5pm in E7-6338

The overwhelming majority of societal, ecological and climate issues of pressing importance are complex systems; nonlinear dynamic interacting systems poorly characterized by linear analyses and Gaussian statistics.
This course introduces the mathematics needed to understand such interactions, including nonlinear dynamics, critical and bifurcation behaviours, large-scale systems and power-law distributions.

The mathematical methods will be motivated by extensive examples and case studies such as global warming, energy shortages, desertification, overpopulation, poverty, and economic instability, to be investigated from a systems engineering perspective that will connect mathematical concepts to real-world examples.
Understand the assumptions and limitations behind linear dynamic / Gaussian systems
Understand the mathematical properties of nonlinear dynamic / power-law systems
Be able to abstract / generalize the impacts and implications of nonlinear systems
Be able to draw connections between macroscopic socio-environmental systems

major_name: Systems Design Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Simulating Neurobiological Systems Fall 2024
This course develops and applies a general framework for understanding neural computation in the context of recent advances in theoretical and experimental neuroscience.
Demonstrate a basic understanding of neural processes, neural mechanisms, theories of neural communication and computation, and theories of neural dynamics.
Converse at a fundamental level with neuroscientists, psychologists, and neural and cogitive modelers.
Design and Analyze simple and complex neural circuits for performing small- and large-scale neural computations.
Apply engineering methods in signal processing, optimization, and control theory, among others, to characterizing and building neural circuits.
Identify problems and solutions that may exploit the advantages of neural computation in an engineering context.

major_name: Systems Design Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Image Processing Fall 2024
Beginning with a discussion of quantitative models of imaging systems, this course moves on to apply methods of linear systems theory and signal processing to image processing.
Simple spatial domain techniques as well as spatial frequency domain methods, and digital filter design for image enhancement and restoration are discussed.
Applications to machine vision, remote sensing, and medical imaging will be emphasized.

Work in a team to complete applied lab design based solutions to problems and prepare a technical report responding to clear instructions (4, 7)
7. Demonstrate an enhanced understanding of linear systems with application to image processing (1)

course_name: SYDE584 - Physiological Systems and Biomedical Design (0.50)
major_name: Systems Design Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Physiological Systems and Biomedical Design Winter 2025
Email: maud.gorbet@uwaterloo.ca
Email: gganjikho@uwaterloo.ca

The structure, functions, and properties of major physiological systems (e.g., musculoskeletal, nervous, cardiovascular, and respiratory) will be presented in relation to modelling physiological systems and the design of biomedical devices (imaging, assistive, and diagnostic).
The structure, functions and properties of some of the major physiological systems (musculoskeletal, nervous, and cardiovascular) will be presented with an engineering science perspective.

Strong emphasis will be given to mechanical, electrical, chemical and biological properties of tissues and their relation to measurements, modeling human systems, and the design of biomedical devices (assistive, orthopedic and diagnostic).
Various aspects of physiological system dysfunctions and how they influence measurements and design of medical devices will be discussed.
Learn and integrate basics of human physiology
Develop an engineering perspective toward understanding biological functions
Develop critical thinking skills for solving biomedical problems and designing sound biomedical technologies
Describe the components/structures of the studied physiological systems (1d)
Identify the relationship between structure and functions in physiological systems (1d, 3b, 3c)
Interpret experimental results (graphs, tables, raw data) to evaluate the effects of disease, aging or a medical device on structure and/or function of physiological systems (3c)
Evaluate biomedical engineering solutions by applying your knowledge of physiology and the scientific methods (2c)
Develop reasoned solutions to address biomedical problems by applying your knowledge of physiology and engineering principles while considering social-economical-ethical impacts (4b, 4c, 9a, 9b)

course_name: SYDE599 - Special Topics in Systems Design Engineering (0.50)
major_name: Systems Design Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Planning for Design of a Sustainable Hospital System Winter 2025
lisa.aultman-hall@uwaterloo.ca
This course deals with selected topics at the undergraduate level in environmental and societal systems, mechatronics and physical systems, or human factors and ergonomics.
Three frameworks or tools ground the course in systems design engineering:
systems thinking (with mapping); and
access and transportation;
green energy; or
Co-laboratory definitions of sustainability and hospital systems;
Summaries and reviews of hospital sustainability literature;
Short design reports of alternative hospital site designs; and
Identify and conceptualize the role of a hospital system in a community and region.
Appreciate the complexity of defining sustainability for a hospital, a complex social technical system.
Clearly define the hospital site as a design problem with a sustainability-based objective.
Identify multiple conceptual design alternatives for the Waterloo hospital site and evaluate the extent to which each meets sustainability goals and objectives using metrics.
Use systems thinking to frame a complex problem and communicate the elements of a system using mapping.
Work effectively in a collaborative team environment by co-developing definitions, documents, and system representations of a complex system.
